qas.question: What pigment was used to paint villas in ancient Rome?
Cinnabar is an ore of what metal?
What mines did Romans use to acquire cinnabar?

answers.text: Almadén, southwest of Madrid, in Spain

qas.question: Along with slaves, who was sent to work in cinnabar mines in Rome?
What color were Roman villas painted?
What was the pigment called that was used for the painting of Roman villas?
What is Mercury a common ore of?
What city is southwest of Almaden?

context: The Romans liked bright colors, and many Roman villas were decorated with vivid <b5_0>red<b5_0/> murals. The pigment used for many of the murals was called <a0_0><b6_0>vermilion<b6_0/><a0_0/>, and it came from <a1_0>the mineral <b7_0>cinnabar<b7_0/><a1_0/>, a common ore of <a2_0>mercury<a2_0/>. It was one of the finest reds of ancient times – the paintings have retained their brightness for more than twenty centuries. The source of cinnabar for the Romans was a group of mines near <a3_0>Almadén, southwest of <b8_0>Madrid<b8_0/>, in Spain<a3_0/>. Working in the mines was extremely dangerous, since mercury is highly toxic; the miners were slaves or <a4_0>prisoners<a4_0/>, and being sent to the cinnabar mines was a virtual death sentence.
